name: PETROV DEFENSE
idea: The most solid response to 1.e4 e5 2.Nf3! Instead of defending e5 with ...Nc6, Black counter-attacks the e4 pawn with ...Nf6. After 3.Nxe5 d6 4.Nf3 Nxe4, the position is symmetrical and solid. Black's plan is simple: equalize with solid play and wait for White's mistakes. It's the favorite defense of World Champions who want a safe draw as Black!
errors_white: Playing 3.Nxe5 Nxe4?? 4.Qe2!: wins a piece (this is actually good for White!)
Trading too many pieces: helps Black equalize
Being too aggressive: the Petrov is solid, forcing leads nowhere
errors_black: Playing 3.Nxe5 Nxe4?? without ...d6 first: loses a piece to Qe2
Being too passive: Black must at least equalize
Forgetting ...d5: this move frees Black's position
development: MANDATORY after 3.Nxe5! Chases the Knight before recapturing e4
Recaptures e4 after ...d6 Nf3, then retreats to d6 or f6 depending on variation
Develop to d6 (active) or e7 (solid) - controls central squares
Develop to f5 or g4 (pins Nf3) - don't leave it locked in
Go to d7 (supports the center) or c6 (after ...c6)
Classical kingside castle after ...Be7 - very safe position

traps.name: Beginner's Trap
traps.desc: 3.Nxe5 Nxe4?? (mistake!) 4.Qe2! and the Ne4 is pinned. If 4...Nf6 5.Nc6+ wins the Queen! AVOID (Black): Always play 3...d6! first to chase the Ne5.

traps.name: Stafford Trap
traps.desc: 3...d6 4.Nxf7?! (dubious gambit) Kxf7 5.Bc4+ White has threats but Black is better after 5...Be6! AVOID (White): Don't play Nxf7 - retreat Nf3 is correct.

traps.name: Cochrane Trap
traps.desc: Cochrane Gambit: 4.Nxf7!? Kxf7 5.d4 - real sacrifice for the attack. If Black accepts poorly, the attack is strong. AVOID (Black): 5...c5! or 5...Be6 with active defense and extra material.

variants.name: Classical Variation
variants.uci: e2e4 e7e5 g1f3 g8f6 f3e5 d7d6 e5f3 f6e4 d2d4 d6d5 f1d3
variants.white_plan: Symmetrical position. Play 0-0, c4 to attack d5, Re1 and look for Nc3 with pressure on the center.
variants.black_plan: Perfect equality! Develop ...Be7, ...0-0, ...Nc6 or ...Nd7. Maintain symmetry and exchange towards a draw.

variants.name: Steinitz Variation
variants.uci: e2e4 e7e5 g1f3 g8f6 f3e5 d7d6 e5f3 f6e4 b1c3
variants.white_plan: Attack the Ne4 immediately! After Nxe4 dxe4, White has easier play with Bc4, 0-0 and d3.
variants.black_plan: Defend the Knight with ...Nf6 or ...Nc6. If Nxe4 dxe4 accept the structure and play ...Bf5, ...Qe7.

variants.name: Three Knights Attack
variants.uci: e2e4 e7e5 g1f3 g8f6 b1c3 b8c6 f1b5
variants.white_plan: Avoid the classical Petrov! Transpose to the Four Knights with Bb5. Active play with 0-0, d3, then Bg5 or Nd5.
variants.black_plan: We exit the pure Petrov. Play ...Bb4 (symmetry), ...Nd4 or ...a6 to chase the Bishop and look for ...d5.
